occurrences.text: you turn over to 2 Peter, just a few pages over and look in the first chapter, you begin to see the introduction here and notice what is said in verse number three. According as his divine power hath given unto us all things that pertain unto life and godliness, through the knowledge of him that hath called us to glory and virtue, notice verse number four, whereby are given unto us exceeding great and precious promises. That by these you might be partakers of the divine nature, having escaped the corruption that is in the world through lust. In 2 Corinthians 1 and verse number 20, we are told that all the promises of God in him are yea and in him, amen, under the glory of God by us, all the promises of God in him are yea. And I'm so thankful that God has given us promises in his Word. And someone said this, it's a statement from yesteryear and it says, as the individual was speaking of promises, it says this, the individual noted, a promise is only as good as the person who makes it. We understand that to be the case, correct? And a promise is only as good as the person who makes it. The character of the promiser is what gives the promise its value. Now think about that. The character of the promiser, the one who's making the promises, the character of that individual is what gives the promise its value.
